bugs.title: CVE-2016-1902 php-symfony: SecureRandom's fallback not secure when OpenSSL fails [epel-6]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2016-1902 php-symfony: SecureRandom's fallback not secure when OpenSSL fails [epel-6]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2016-1902 php-symfony: SecureRandom's fallback not secure when OpenSSL fails

long_desc.thetext:
The SecureRandom Symfony class goal is to generate secure random numbers. Several strategies are used depending on PHP's configuration. On PHP installations where the random_bytes() function is not available, Symfony falls back to using openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(). If that does not work, Symfony generates a secure random number using uniqid() and mt_rand(), which are not suitable for cryptographic contexts.

External references:

https://symfony.com/blog/cve-2016-1902-securerandom-s-fallback-not-secure-when-openssl-fails

bugs.title: CVE-2016-4423 php-symfony: Large username storage in session [epel-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2016-4423 php-symfony: Large username storage in session [epel-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2016-4423 php-symfony: Large username storage in session

long_desc.thetext:
When an authentication form is submitted by the user and if the user does not exist, the submitted username is stored in the session. If an attacker submit multiple requests with large usernames, he can potentially fill up the session storage.

External references:

https://symfony.com/blog/cve-2016-4423-large-username-storage-in-session
